text: So do you guys think it’s a good idea to reverse engineer a company’s app in preparation for the interview?

>Why do you want to work here?

>Well I can't bear how SHIT your app is so I'm going to fix it. When do I start?
I got curious about the geocaching app after noticing a bug in their maps implementation
Seen some companies actually post their gradle deps into the offer.
I decided to crack their app open to take a peek
Also the open source attributions are fair play to check what they use
noticed a few concerns. I thought it would be something interesting to talk about
But check their ToS if they have something about reversing
I’m not trying to reverse engineer their API or anything
just poke around the app to see what they are using
Nah those clauses are usually really broad
> Reverse engineer, decompile, or attempt to extract the source code of the software associated with our services.
See
:disappointed:
I mean in a tech interview they might not care so much about it but you can never know
Some might take it worse than others. Assess the situation and decide if it would do any good or not
No generalised answer here I guess
Hmmm You’re right I guess.
Personally I wouldn't mind cause I reverse stuff myself regularly and sometimes that came in handy already so ¯\_(ツ)_/¯
Yeah I think it’s a useful skill…
I just don’t want to blow this interview
I think the guys are pretty good
I'd say focus on the positive things. Mentioning bugs in their app out of the blue could be seen negatively really quick.
If they ask you how you would improve the app don't go low level bug hunting, maybe keep the level a bit higher
The job offer there indeed looks nice. Good luck with the interview :)
Haha I did issue a bug report on my interview with m&s
Generally I'd say if they are bitching about reverse engineering and suggested improvements then that's not a good place to work
But don't mention it unless speaking to the engineer
Anyone with any shred of understanding of the risks of putting your IP out there should understand this
Once it’s out there… the only thing that would keep people from picking your IP apart is if you write it in VB
Agree
it’s worth doing it anyways, but you could say bring it up in vague/general terms
if you’re talking to an engineer and it’s a nice convo you should say you toyed with the app, I’d be glad to hear that from a candidate
Hmm… looks like mixed opinions on this
very much seems like a ‘read the room’ sort of deal
tries to read the room. The room has no words. <@U08GFT5V5|nish> could not read the room
Now I want soft pretzels

you don’t see shit

you step in a bottomless pit. should’ve looked around more.
a healer from your party revives you. unfortunately, he didn’t roll a perfect 20 so now you’re a nodejs hipster

I would watch a dev role playing game
Possible plugin?
Your task is to download a picture into a view. - I add Glide to the project - _rolls 1_ - You accidentally add Fresco instead.
that would be fun af

Remove Fresco.
_you roll 1_
You’ve created a black hole that consumes you and everything around you.
You hear a whisper in the darkness.
> You have a meeting with your client, you attempt to convince them to use a framework. What do you recommend?
_I would like to add you to my professional network on linkedin_
Someone set up a story for this and then we do the next androidchatchat playing it
who gonna be the DM
Obviously <@U053PPGDC>
He is the host afterall
recommends that they use PhoneGap
> The dice is rolled… he rolls a 2
> Clients agree to use Kotlin
/gif noooooooooooooo
My discord bot has a dice roll plugin. Can port that :D
Ok… So I guess we’ll need IPC for this then
We can make it kind of like zork
<@U08GFT5V5> never say you reversed engineered their software
it can backfire a lot
instead talk about the bug and that you "assume" that it was probably caused by "such an implementation detail" and that you would fix it "like that"
some devs even will think you are shitting on their software if you say you reversed engineered their app and found how shitty it is
it's basically a minefield

> some devs even will think you are shitting on their software if you say you reversed engineered their app and found how shitty it is

Probably not the best attitude for a dev to be having
yes absolutely but here is the thing. It matters a lot on the way you say what you say
Before calling anyone’s software sh*tty, I always think about the old saying, there is no such thing as “good code"
in a first interaction between two people things can very easily misenterpeted in sensitive subjects
Yeah I understand your pov
yes but you don't want to start a convo that way
you can bring it up after you are hired very easily
but in an interview you have to be as neutral as possible
assuming I get the job
basically you can't bring up anything controversial in an interview
and reverse engineering is controversial
Good point
because controversial things matter a lot depending on the person
on the other hand if you definitely don't want to work with a person that doesn't like his software reverse engineered then you should bring it up to see his reaction

<@U08GFT5V5> btw I remember you mentioned that you had holes in your java thread knowledge. I have heard from many that the _Java Concurency in Practice_ book is one of the best <https://www.amazon.com/dp/0321349601>

attachments.title: Java Concurrency in Practice: Brian Goetz, Tim Peierls, Joshua Bloch, Joseph Bowbeer, David Holmes, Doug Lea: 0785342349603: Amazon.com: Books
attachments.text: Java Concurrency in Practice [Brian Goetz, Tim Peierls, Joshua Bloch, Joseph Bowbeer, David Holmes, Doug Lea] on <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>. *FREE* shipping on qualifying offers. I was fortunate indeed to have worked with a fantastic team on the design and implementation of the concurrency features added to the Java platform in Java 5.0 and Java 6. Now this same team provides the best explanation yet of these new features
attachments.fallback: Java Concurrency in Practice: Brian Goetz, Tim Peierls, Joshua Bloch, Joseph Bowbeer, David Holmes, Doug Lea: 0785342349603: Amazon.com: Books

not right now though
Need to work on my own book
So I got this today

```
Dear Nish,

Thank you for taking the time to apply for the Android Mobile Apps Developer position at Crossover.

The application process has been extremely competitive, and we greatly appreciate your contribution to that competition. After carefully considering your application, we are sorry to inform you that your Project Evaluation did not score high enough to proceed. You can see our evaluator's comments at the end of this email.

Although we are unable to continue with your application, we want to thank your for your interest in Crossover and for the valuable time and effort you have invested in this process.

We wish you the best in your professional endeavors!



Thank you,
The Crossover Team
```

The saga has finally come to an end
There were no evaluations
What do you mean "There were no evaluations"?
He didn't comment on your code?
But who cares, they missed out
<@U061HDV96> haven’t you been following the saga?

tl;dr

1. Apply to company literally offering Bernie Sanders min. wage. Ironically they claim to only hire the top 1% of developers

2. Entire process is automated. Stage 2 is tech interview. 20 multiple choice questions, 2 generic coding problems. Questions were out of date, plain bad and ridiculous. See my blog post for more

3. Managed to pass the interview onto next stage. Android app that requires 3 days to finish. Makes no sense for tech interview. So I decided to write to the guys criticizing the hiring process.

4. Receive email berating me as not being able to “live up to the challenge”, their employees are too busy going on holidays and spending time with their families at $30,000 a year.

5. Receive (automated) email saying that I should submit the challenge task.

6. Now I receive (automated) rejection email.
Step 4 was the only stage where I interacted with a human during the entire process
<@U08GFT5V5> often when I'm asked to write a sample app they offer to pay me for my time
I'm guessing that didn't happen here
<@U053LEHJN> They want to pay devs $30,000 a year
What are they going to offer for sample apps?
$7.5 an hour?
<https://www.crossover.com/> this one?

They sound very conceited
<https://blog.nishtahir.com/2016/08/09/why-automated-recruitment-tools-fail/>

attachments.title: Why automated recruitment tools fail
attachments.text: It's no secret I've been on the job hunt for a couple of weeks now. The hunt for a great team to work with is as much a challenge for me as it is for companies. Recruiters are supposed to somehow help relieve frustration on both sides of the spectrum
attachments.fallback: Another dev's two cents: Why automated recruitment tools fail
